title: 108_s387
content: The "Geriatric Care Act of 2003" includes provisions for extending eligibility periods for geriatric graduate medical education and Medicare coverage of care coordination services. The "Geriatric Care Act of 2003" extends eligibility periods for geriatric graduate medical education programs and fellowship programs approved by the Secretary. It also amends sections of the Social Security Act related to board eligibility and residency periods. The amendments made by this section apply to cost reporting periods beginning 6 months after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. Disregard of certain geriatric residents against graduate medical education limitations. The Geriatric Care Act of 2003 amends the Social Security Act to increase the limitation for geriatric fellowships in the field of allopathic or osteopathic medicine for hospitals, rural health clinics, or Federally qualified health centers. Up to 3 residents enrolled in a fellowship will not be counted towards the total number of full-time equivalent residents. The Geriatric Care Act of 2003 amends the Social Security Act to increase the limitation for geriatric fellowships in allopathic or osteopathic medicine. Up to 3 residents in a fellowship will not be counted towards the total number of full-time equivalent residents. The Geriatric Care Act of 2003 increases the limitation for geriatric fellowships in medicine. Clause (ix) is added to amend 42 U.S.C. 1395ww(d)(5)(B) regarding hospitals and specific clauses. The Medicare coverage is expanded to include care coordination and assessment services for individuals with serious and disabling chronic conditions. This amendment defines these services and introduces the role of a care coordinator. The term 'care coordination and assessment services' refers to services provided to individuals with serious chronic conditions by a care coordinator under a prescribed plan of care for the purpose of coordination and assessment. This includes initial and annual assessments to monitor health status and make necessary care plan adjustments. The care coordination and assessment services involve developing and revising plans of care, managing medical services, monitoring medications, providing patient and family education, offering self-management services, and facilitating consultations with healthcare professionals. The curr_chunk discusses the coordination of healthcare professionals for emergency consultations, managing transitions among healthcare professionals, facilitating continuity of care, providing information and referral to hospice services, and offering other medical and health care services. The curr_chunk discusses additional medical and health care services that may be available to eligible beneficiaries who have made an election under this section for effective care coordination. The Secretary may specify additional benefits to encourage the receipt of care coordination services. The curr_chunk defines an individual with a serious and disabling chronic condition as someone who requires substantial assistance with daily activities, has a level of disability requiring medical management, or needs supervision for health and safety. The curr_chunk defines a care coordinator as an individual or entity working in collaboration with a physician, who has entered into a care coordination agreement with the Secretary and meets specified criteria. The curr_chunk outlines the requirements for a care coordination agreement, including a one-year duration, submission of reports on patients' status and outcomes, and renewal criteria. The Secretary may require a care coordinator to submit one report per year with specified terms and conditions. Activities of daily living include eating, toileting, transferring, bathing, dressing, and continence. Rural health clinics and Federally qualified health centers are eligible sites for care coordination services. Payment and coinsurance requirements under the Social Security Act are amended. The payment basis for care coordination and assessment services under the Social Security Act is amended to be 100 percent of the actual charge or the amount determined by the Secretary. Payment under the physician fee schedule is also adjusted. Coinsurance in outpatient hospital settings is eliminated. The Social Security Act is amended to include care coordination and assessment services, with specific definitions and exceptions for care coordinators and physician referrals in designated health services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will define terms and establish procedures to implement these provisions, effective January 1, 2004.
